revision.text:
{{Year in Monaco|2005}}
The following lists events that happened during '''[[2005]] in [[Monaco]]'''.
==Incumbents== *[[List of rulers of Monaco|Monarch]]: [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Rainier III]]<ref name="rainierdeath" /> (died 6 April 2005) [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Albert II]] (succeeded Rainier III, his father, as Sovereign Prince)<ref name="rainierdeath" /> *[[Minister of State (Monaco)|State Minister]]: [[Patrick Leclercq]] and [[Jean-Paul Proust]]
==Events==
===January to June===
* April 6 - [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Rainier III]] died at the age of 81. Having assumed the throne on May 9, 1949, he was Europe's longest reigning monarch.<ref name="rainierdeath">{{cite web|title=Monaco's Prince Rainier dead at 81|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829075843/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/7400308/ns/world_news/t/monacos-prince-rainier-dead/|website=NBC News|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
* June 1 - [[Patrick Leclercq]] stepped down as Minister of State. [[Jean-Paul Proust]] assumed the office.<ref>{{cite web|title=Disparition de M. Jean-Paul Proust, ancient Ministre d'État de la Principauté de Monaco|url=http://www.gouv.mc/Actualites/Disparition-de-M.-Jean-Paul-Proust-ancien-Ministre-d-Etat-de-la-Principaute-de-Monaco|website=Actualité (news)|publisher=Gouvernement de Monaco|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
* June/July - [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|The Sovereign Prince]] officially acknowledged his paternity of [[Alexandre Grimaldi-Coste]], who was at that time living in [[Villefranche-sur-Mer]] with his mother, [[Nicole Coste]].<ref name="throne">{{cite web|title=Bachelor prince takes throne of Monaco|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205122638/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/13/world/europe/bachelor-prince-takes-throne-of-monaco.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
* July 12 - [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]] attended a solemn [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]]<ref name="keystothecity" /> and received the keys to the city amid a fantastic celebration, involving fireworks<ref name="keystothecity">{{cite web|title=Monaco's Albert II assumes throne|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060426235831/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4674109.stm|website=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref> and live music by [[U2]] and [[Pink Floyd]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Prince Rainier's son takes throne of Monaco dynasty|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2005/jul/12/20050712-094351-4285r/|website=The Washington Times (US)|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
===July to December===
==References== <references />

{{refimprove|date=February 2013}} [[File:Bacalhau Ze Do Pipo.jpg|thumb|''Bacalhau à Zé do Pipo'']] '''Bacalhau à Zé do Pipo''' (literally Bacalhau ''à la'' Zé do Pipo) is a common codfish ([[bacalhau]]) dish in [[Portugal]]. It is an oven baked dish, consisting in layers of bacalhau (previously boiled in milk), onion (or [[Pickled cucumber|pickles]]), mashed potatoes and [[mayonnaise]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Marcia Algranti|title=Cozinha para homens e mulheres que gostam de seus homens|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LTqinKcD7Z4C|accessdate=3 April 2012|year=2002|publisher=Editora Cultrix|isbn=978-85-316-0746-2|page=52}}</ref> Although mayonnaise is not traditionally used in [[Portuguese cuisine]], this dish is considered typical. It is usually garnished with olives and/or peppers. The recipe originates from [[Porto]] and is named after its creator, ''Zé do Pipo'', who owned a famous [[restaurant]] in that city during the 1960s. He won a national gastronomic contest with this main course, making many restaurants adopt it in their menus and popularizing it through the country to this day.
==See also== * [[List of casserole dishes]]
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bacalhau a Ze do Pipo}} [[Category:Fish dishes]] [[Category:Portuguese cuisine]] [[Category:Casserole dishes]]
{{portugal-cuisine-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Kautokeino komm.svg|thumb|right|120px]] The '''coat of arms of [[Kautokeino]]/Guovdageainnu''' was designed by Arvid Sveen and awarded to the municipality by royal resolution on 4 September 1987. It is a gold [[lavvu]] on a blue [[Field (heraldry)|field]]. The lávvu is a traditional temporary dwelling similar to the [[tipi]] and symbolises the municipality's traditions from the [[Sami people]], gold symbolises the sami culture's richness and diversity and the blue field symbolises the [[arctic]] climate and nature.
==Blazon== The official [[blazon]] is written in Norwegian. It is here also translated to English, in the traditional way blazons are written.
*[[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: ''I blått en gull lavvo'' *[[English language|English]]: ''Azure a lavvu Or''
==See also== *[[Sami institutional symbols]]
==Sources== *[http://www.kautokeino.kommune.no/finnmark/kautokeino/kautokeinok.nsf/id/3E53FB55BDF6CA3C41256E2F003DE12B?OpenDocument Kautokeino municipality web page on the coat of arms (Norwegian)] *[http://www.riksarkivet.no/webfelles/kommunevaapen/vaapen/kautokeino.html Norwegian national archives on the arms]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kautokeino}} [[Category:Municipal coats of arms in Norway]] [[Category:Coats of arms with buildings]]

{{inline|date=November 2014}}{{Infobox Coat of arms |name = Coat of arms of the
Prince of Liechtenstein |image = Staatswappen-Liechtensteins.svg |image_width = 200 |middle = |middle_width = |middle_caption = |lesser = Lesser Coat of arms of Liechtenstein.svg |lesser_width = 50 |lesser_caption = The Lesser Arms of Liechtenstein |armiger = [[Hans Adam II, Prince of Liechtenstein]] |year_adopted = |crest = |torse = |shield = Quarterly: I Or, an eagle displayed Sable crowned and armed Or charged with a [[crescent]] treflée, issuing from the middle thereof a cross pattée Argent ([[Silesia]]); II barry of eight Or and Sable, a crown of rue bendways throughout Vert ([[Kuenring]]); III per pale Gules and Argent ([[Duchy of Troppau]]); IV Or, a [[harpy]] displayed Sable the human parts Argent crowned and armed Or ([[Cirksena]]); on a point entée Azure, a [[Bugle (instrument)|bugle-horn]] stringed Or ([[Duchy of Krnov|Duchy of Jägerndorf]]); en surtout, an inescutcheon per fess or and Gules ([[Princely House of Liechtenstein]]) |supporters = |compartment = |motto = |orders = |other_elements = Behind the shield a Princely mantle Purpure lined ermine ensigned with the Princely hat |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''Arms of [[Liechtenstein]]''' are the armorial bearings of the [[Prince of Liechtenstein]], currently [[Hans-Adam II]]. As the sovereign emblem of the Prince, its use is restricted to the Prince and members of his House, though private individuals are permitted to use the arms if it is in the interest of the State. The arms are a history of the House, and show the many different regions and families with which Liechtenstein has been involved, either by conquest or by marriage. ==Description== The first quarter shows the arms of [[Silesia]]; the second the arms of the [[Kuenring]] family {{ill|Kuenringer|de}}; the third the arms of the [[Duchy of Troppau]]; and the fourth the arms of the [[County of Rietberg]]. The base is occupied by the arms of the [[Duchy of Krnov|Duchy of Jägerndorf]], while the arms of the Princely House itself are placed on an [[inescutcheon]]. The whole shield is surrounded by a purple or red mantle with [[Ermine (heraldry)|ermine]] lining and fringes and tassels of gold. At the top is placed the Princely hat. The arms of the Princely House are sometimes used alone, and thus form the Lesser Arms of Liechtenstein. When shown alone, the arms are usually ensigned by the Princely hat. ==See also== *[[Flag of Liechtenstein]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{de icon}} [http://www.gesetze.li/Seite1.jsp?LGBlm=1982058 Original Law text] {{Liechtenstein topics}} {{Coats of arms of Europe}} [[Category:National symbols of Liechtenstein]] [[Category:National coats of arms|Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crowns|Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Coats of arms with eagles|Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Coats of arms with horns (instrument)|Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Royal arms of European monarchs|Liechtenstein]] {{Liechtenstein-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Conquistador" | image = | caption = | year = 1989 | country = Portugal | artist = Iei Or, [[Pedro Luís Neves]],
Ricardo, Joaquim Andrade,
Dora Fidalgo, Sandra Fidalgo | as = [[Da Vinci (band)|Da Vinci]] | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Ricardo Landum | lyricist = Pedro Luís Neves | conductor = Luís Duarte | place = 16th | points = 39 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1989pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Voltarei | prev_link = Voltarei | next = Há sempre alguém | next_link = Há sempre alguém }} '''"Conquistador"''' (Conqueror) was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1989]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Da Vinci (band)|Da Vinci]]. The song reminisces about the former Portuguese colonial possessions worldwide. Lead singer Tei Or takes the role of the Portuguese state and sings that she has been to [[Brazil]], [[Praia]], [[Bissau]], [[Angola]], [[Mozambique]], [[Goa]], [[Macau]] and "[[Timor]]" (the last a reference to [[East Timor]]). The song was performed ninth on the night, following [[Norway]]'s [[Britt Synnøve Johansen|Britt Synnøve]] with "[[Venners nærhet]]" and preceding [[Sweden]]'s [[Tommy Nilsson]] with "[[En dag]]". At the close of voting, it had received 39 points, placing 16th in a field of 22. It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1990|1990 Contest]] by [[Nucha (singer)|Nucha]] with ''[[Há Sempre Alguém]]''. {{Eurovision Song Contest 1989}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1989]] [[Category:1989 songs]] {{portugal-stub}} {{1980s-song-stub}}

page.title: Coral Bell School of Asia Pacific Affairs

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{ Infobox University | |name = Coral Bell School of Asia Pacific Affairs |image = |established = 1946 |director = |parent = [[Australian National University]] |city = [[Canberra]] |state = Australian Capital Territory |country = Australia |coor = {{coord|-35.2818|149.1201|display=title}} |website = [http://rspas.anu.edu.au/index.php RSPAS home] |location = ANU Hedley Bull Centre, HC Coombs Building |footnotes = |}}
The '''Coral Bell School of Asia Pacific Affairs''' is a constituent of the College of Asia and the Pacific, but was formerly part of the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, ANU, which was founded in 1946 as part of the Institute of Advanced Studies at the [[Australian National University]] in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory. In 2015 it was renamed in honour of Coral Bell, a leading Australian scholar of international politics.<ref>[[Foreign Policy Research Institute]], [http://thinktanks.fpri.org/research-school-pacific-and-asian-studies Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831031121/http://thinktanks.fpri.org/research-school-pacific-and-asian-studies |date=31 August 2011 }}; retrieved 2011-05-16</ref>
==History== First known as the Research School for Pacific Studies (RSPacS), the research school began as one of the foundation schools of the Institute of Advanced Studies at ANU.<ref>The historical background to the foundation of the Research School of Pacific Studies within the ANU is documented in Stephen Foster and Margaret Varghese, ''The Making of the Australian National University, 1946–1966'', St Leonards: Allen and Unwin, 1966; Reprinted ANU E Press, 2009.</ref> In the late 1940s [[Raymond Firth]], an eminent international scholar from the London School of Economics, was asked to join a group of other academics to advise on the creation of the first research schools within the ANU. Other leading scholars in the group included [[Mark Oliphant]] (physical sciences), [[Sir (William) Keith Hancock|Keith Hancock]] (social sciences), and Nobel prize-winner [[Howard Florey]] (medical sciences). Firth was responsible for advising on regional studies, especially Pacific studies. Following the recommendations of this group, a number of research schools were established at the ANU to serve as national centres of study in Australia in the post-war period.
During the next several decades the RSPacS built up a strong international reputation for work on Pacific studies (including Papua New Guinea) and Southeast Asia. The first Director and first professor of economics in the RSPacS was [[John Crawford (economist)|Sir John Crawford]]. Crawford's interests in development in Asia set a direction for economics in the research school. He was also widely recognised as an excellent academic administrator who served as both Vice-Chancellor, and later Chancellor, of the ANU.<ref>A volume edited by L.T. Evans and J.D.B. Miller, ''Policy and Practice: Essays in honour of Sir John Crawford'', Canberra, ANU Press, 1987, provides an appreciation of the man and his work.</ref> The work of the research school during this period was strongly interdisciplinary. For example, as well as research in economics, international relations, human geography and anthropology in the Asia-Pacific region, another major development of the school was the creation of the ''[[Pacific Linguistics]]'' publishing unit by [[Stephen Wurm|Professor Stephen Wurm]] in the early 1960s. Since the establishment of the unit, ''Pacific Linguistics'' has published several hundred volumes of dictionaries, grammars, and other linguistic studies on the Asia-Pacific region, particularly Oceania and Southeast Asia.
In the earlier form of the research school, staff of the RSPacS were frequently involved in public discussion about Pacific and Asian affairs<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48130504 |title="Should Send Observers To Peking". |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=22 May 1954 |accessdate=17 November 2012 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Also the genesis of the RSPAS can be seen in comments by Bruce in 1952<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69419377 |title=AUSTRALIA HAS BECOME THE BRIDGEHEAD BETWEEN EAST AND WEST. |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Tasmania)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie, Tas. |date=24 October 1952 |accessdate=17 November 2012 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Due to the earlier focus on Pacific studies, the RSPacS supported research locations with housing for visiting researchers; the Suva Flats in Fiji were one such location<ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies; Grimshaw, P. G; Australian National University. [[Pacific Manuscripts Bureau]] | title=Records of the Australian National University, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Suva Flats, Fiji, 1971–2005 | publication-date=1971 | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/39577325 | accessdate=17 November 2012 }}</ref>
For a range of reasons, including significant changes in the balance of power in Southeast Asia in the late 1960s and the following decade, during the 1970s and 1980s there was a decline in Asian regional studies in Europe and North America. Partly as a result, many scholars from North America and Europe with an interest in Asia spent time at the ANU to work within the RSPacS. Well-known scholars from North America who visited the school in the 1970s and 1980s included Professor Bruce Glassburner (economics, University of California, Davis), Professor [[Anne Krueger]] (later the chief economist of the World Bank and first deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund), Professor [[Herb Grubel]] (Simon Fraser University, Canada), and many others.
During the 1970s and 1980s an increasing proportion of the work of the school shifted to Southeast Asia from the Pacific. Many scholarly books, journal articles and other studies were produced following research in countries such as Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, and so on. Reflecting the fact that "the balance of research activity in the School... has shifted significantly from the Pacific towards Asia in recent years and will continue to do so", in 1994 the name of the school was changed to the Research School of Pacific ''and Asian'' Studies (RSPAS)<ref>ANU heritage, [http://heritage.anu.edu.au/site1/_includes/Files/429_RSPAS.pdf "RSPS", p. 3] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408102602/http://heritage.anu.edu.au/site1/_includes/Files/429_RSPAS.pdf |date=8 April 2011 }} citing "Minutes of the 251st meeting of the Board of the Institute of Advanced Studies", 18 November 1993; retrieved 2011-05-16</ref> RSPAS developed along multidisciplinary lines, encompassing [[anthropology]], [[archaeology]], economics, history, [[human geography]], [[international relations]], [[linguistics]], [[political science]],<ref>[http://www.auspsa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=6&Itemid=16 Australian Political Studies Association] (APSA); retrieved 2011-05-16</ref> [[resource management]] and [[strategic defence studies]].<ref>ANU heritage [http://heritage.anu.edu.au/site1/_includes/Files/429_RSPAS.pdf "RSPS", p. 1] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408102602/http://heritage.anu.edu.au/site1/_includes/Files/429_RSPAS.pdf |date=8 April 2011 }}</ref> Over time, within the overall departmental structure of the school, certain special areas of study emerged such as the [[Indonesia Project]] which focused on studies of the Indonesian economy as well as other aspects of developments in Indonesia.
At various stages internal ANU and external factors affected the school – such as in 1997 when it was announced that the school was required to reduce staff numbers<ref>Shorter, Damon (1997) ''Research school to cut staff by 25%'' – ANU Reporter, Volume 28, No.6, Wednesday 25 June 1997, p.1 – the Division of Archaeology and Natural History was predicted to be closed down, and the reason given was Federal government funding cuts at that time</ref>
In 2010, following a major review of the organisational arrangements within the ANU, the RSPAS was reduced in status in line with other changes to other research schools across the ANU. Shortly afterwards, a new ''College of Asia and the Pacific''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asiapacific.anu.edu.au/|title=Home|website=Asiapacific.anu.edu.au|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> was established which took over much of the work of former RSPAS.<ref>ANU, Office of the Vice-Chancellor, [http://info.anu.edu.au/ovc/Executive/040PP_University_Structure/academic_structure University Structure]; retirieved 2011-05-16</ref><ref>Kipnis in his introduction to his book dates the demise of RSPAS as 31 December 2009 {{Citation | author1=Kipnis, Andrew B | title=Governing educational desire : culture, politics, and schooling in China | publication-date=2011 | publisher=The University of Chicago Press | isbn=978-0-226-43755-2 }}</ref> ==Departments and Centres== The Bell School consists of seven departments or centres. * Asia Pacific College of Diplomacy * Department of International Relations * Department of Political and Social Change * Department of Pacific Affairs * Strategic and Defence Studies Centre * Centre for Democratic Institutions * Contemporary China Centre ==Programs== The Bell School offers one undergraduate and six postgraduate coursework programs.
'''Undergraduate Program''' * Bachelor of International Security Studies '''Postgraduate Programs''' * Graduate Diploma of International Affairs * Master of Diplomacy * Master of Strategic Studies * Master of International Relations * Master of Political Science * Master of Military and Defence Studies
The School also contributes undergraduate and graduate courses in International Relations, security studies, strategic studies, political science, political and social change and Asia and the Pacific studies. ==Higher Degree by Research== The Bell School offers graduate research programs. Students undertake their research at one of the School's departments or centres and are awarded Master of Philosophy or Doctor of Philosophy degrees when they complete their studies. ==Publications and outreach== During its existence, scholars from the RSPacS and RSPAS produced a large number of books and journal articles as well as various other publications that reported on its work and subjects within its scope<ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=Quarterly bulletin | publication-date=2000 | publisher=Australian National University, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | issn=1443-7104 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=The Asia-Pacific magazine | publication-date=1997 | publisher=Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University | issn=1329-6663 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=New Asia-Pacific review | publication-date=1996 | publisher=Dragon Media, Inc | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/15949464 | accessdate=17 November 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=Conversations : occasional writing from the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | publication-date=2000 | publisher=The Australian National University | issn=1444-0849 }}</ref> For example, one of the major achievements of the research school was the establishment of the ''Bulletin of Indonesian Economic Studies'' by Professor [[Heinz Arndt]] in the mid-1960s. Now in publication for over 40 years, the ''Bulletin'' has documented the development of the Indonesian economy and is today the leading international journal dealing with the economic development of Indonesia.<ref>Arndt has documented the work surrounding the development of the ''Bulletin of Indonesian Economic Studies'' in his memoire, ''A Course Through Life: Memoire of an Australian Economist'', Canberra, National Centre for Development Studies, ANU, 1985.</ref>
Other work on the region included support for the major annual ''Indonesia Update'' conference in Canberra where Australian and overseas experts discussed the state of development in Indonesia. The ''Update'' conference, which is now organised within the College of Asia and the Pacific, leads to the publication of a conference volume. During the 1980s and 1990s, the RSPAS was joint publisher of the conference volume in cooperation with the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iseas.edu.sg/|title=Home|website=www.iseas.edu.sg|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> in Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crawford.anu.edu.au/acde/ip/publications/publications_ius.php|title=Indonesia Update Series Publications - Indonesia Project - ANU|website=Crawford.anu.edu.au|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref>
The number of linked publication series of the staff RSPAS is of considerable size covering its scope – with publications relating to Australian, Pacific, and Asian subjects <ref>{{cite web|url=http://coombs.anu.edu.au/RPN/rspas-print-archive.htm|title=Home|website=Coombs.anu.edu.au|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> However following the change in arrangements in the ANU in 2010, some projects effectively closed down.<ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=China heritage newsletter | publication-date=2005 | publisher=China Heritage Project, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/19892125 | accessdate=17 November 2012 }}</ref>
Pandanus Books was a publishing arm of RSPAS which produced a range of significant publications relative to south east Asian studies, it was wound down in 2006<ref>{{Citation | title=Pandanus Books to Wind Down | journal=Bookseller + Publisher Magazine | publication-date=April 2006 | volume=85 | issue=9 | pages=9 | issn=1833-5403 }}</ref>
===Internet=== A significant presence for the RSPAS on the internet was the RSPAS-based work ''Asian Studies WWW Monitor'' supported by Dr T.Matthew Ciolek. The ''Monitor'' was established in April 1994 and operated until January 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://coombs.anu.edu.au/asia-www-monitor.html|title=Home|website=Coombs.anu.edu.au|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://asia-www-monitor.blogspot.com.au/|title=The Best of the Asian Studies WWW Monitor|date=27 January 2011|website=Asia-www-monitor.blogspot.com.au|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> Later, the ''Pacific Studies WWW Monitor'' (ISSN 1443-8976) modelled on the Asian Studies monitor was established in April 2000.
===Conferences=== Subject areas of the conferences that RSPAS conducted or shared with other bodies were extensive in their coverage of Pacific and Asian areas of interest to Australia,<ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies; Australian National University. Research School of Pacific Studies | title=Annual report | publication-date=1994 | publisher=Australian National University, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | issn=1442-1852 }}</ref> this also subsequently attracted researchers with experience who would go on to work in Australian government agencies or authorities, or otherwise government would co-opt RSPAS staff onto their bodies.<ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=Directory of research | publication-date=2000 | publisher=Pandanus Books, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | issn=1443-7090 }}</ref> Of significance of the government relationship between RSPAS and the government is the title of the doctoral these by van Konkelenberg who wrote about ''The relationship between the Australian National University's Research School of Pacific Studies and the federal government 1946–1975.<ref>{{Citation |author1=Van Konkelenberg |author2=Jude Nicholas | title=Australia's Cold War university : the relationship between the Australian National University's Research School of Pacific Studies and the federal government 1946–1975 | publication-date=2009 | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/158913681 | accessdate=17 November 2012 }}</ref>
==Resources ==
===Collections===
The various divisions or sections within RSPAS had collections of materials in relation to the study areas that were on a par or complementary with that held by the [[National Library of Australia]]<ref>{{Citation | authors=ANU Research School of Asian and Pacific Studies. Cartographic Services | title=Index to Papua New Guinea 1:100,000 topographic survey maps held in Cartographic Services, up to 2004. Topography | publication-date=2004 | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/28578872 | accessdate=17 November 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | authors=Australian National University. Pacific Manuscripts Bureau | title=Tam-tam, 1980–1984 | publication-date=1980 | publisher=Tam-tam | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/37847914 | accessdate=17 November 2012 }}</ref>
===Coombs Building===
For much of its history, the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies was housed in the Coombs Building, a notable architectural icon on the ANU campus. The building, named after leading Australian economist H.C. Coombs, was inaugurated on 11 September 1964. A set of interlinked hexagons –- originally two, with third added later, together with a lecture theatre and extension—the Coombs Building was the hive in which research and teaching were carried out on the Asia-Pacific region.<ref>''The Coombs: A House of Memories'', is a set of some thirty-five personal recollections by scholars and staff who spent time in the building. {{Citation | author1=Coombs, H. C. | author2=Lal, Brij V | author3=Ley, Allison | others=Australian National University. Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | title=The Coombs : a house of memories | publication-date=2006 | publisher=Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies | isbn=978-1-920942-88-5 }}</ref>
==Directors== * Sir [[John Crawford (economist)|John Crawford]], 1960–1967<ref name="heritage5">ANU heritage, [http://heritage.anu.edu.au/site1/_includes/Files/429_RSPAS.pdf "RSPS", p. 5] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408102602/http://heritage.anu.edu.au/site1/_includes/Files/429_RSPAS.pdf |date=8 April 2011 }}; retrieved 2011-05-16</ref> * Professor [[Oskar Spate]], 1967–1972<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor [[Anthony Low]], 1973–1975<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor [[Wang Gungwu]], 1975–1980<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor Gerard Ward, 1980–1993<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor [[Merle Ricklefs]], 1993–1998<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor [[James J. Fox]], 1998–2006<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor [[Robin Jeffrey]], 2006–2008;<ref name="heritage5"/> * Professor Andrew MacIntyre, 2008– ;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asiapacific.anu.edu.au/about/governance|title=Our governance|date=10 October 2012|website=Asiapacific.anu.edu.au|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Firth, Raymond. [[File:Ett.jpg|thumb]] '''East Timor Trading''' is a corporate group involved in many businesses in [[East Timor|Timor-Leste]]. They own and operate the duty-free shops at Dili International Airport, and run wholesalers and distributors of grocery items, soft drinks, wines, beers, spirits and many more.
With exclusive agency rights of about 30 multinational companies, they are a progressive company growing rapidly in Timor Leste.<ref>http://www.easttimor-timorleste.com/Suppliers_East_Timor_Leste_Dili.htm</ref>
==References== <references />

{{Infobox mountain | name = Grmovšek Lodge Below Big Kopa Peak | native_name = Grmovškov dom pod Veliko Kopo | photo = Razglednica Grmovškovega doma pod Veliko Kopo 1960.jpg | photo_caption = Postcard of the Grmovšek Lodge
Below Big Kopa Peak (1960) | elevation_m = 1377 | elevation_ref = | prominence_m = | prominence_ref = | listing = | map = Slovenia | map_caption = | label_position = right | location = [[Slovenia]] | range = [[Pohorje]] | coordinates = {{coord|46|30|11.160|N|15|12|54.720|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = | age = | last_eruption = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} The '''Grmovšek Lodge Below Big Kopa Peak''' ({{lang-sl|Grmovškov dom pod Veliko Kopo}}; 1377 m) is [[mountain hut]] under Big Kopa on the westernmost and highest part of [[Pohorje]]. The hut was built in 1937 and soon became important for hiking and wintersports. In 1942 it was burnt down, the hikers built new one in 1947, but it was also burnt down the same year. The third hut opened in 1954 and was named after Miloš Grmovšek, the then president of the Slovenj Gradec Hiking Club ({{lang|sl|PD Slovenj Gradec}}). ==Starting points== *1½h from the [[Ribnica Lodge]] ({{lang|sl|Ribniška koča}}) *2¾h from the village of [[Dovže]] ==See also== * [[Slovenian Mountain Hiking Trail]] ==References== * Slovenska planinska pot, Planinski vodnik, PZS, 2012, Milenko Arnejšek - Prle, Andraž Poljanec {{ISBN|978-961-6870-04-7}} ==External links== * [http://www.hiking-trail.net/mountain/grmovskov_dom_mountain_hut/4/520 Routes, Description & Photos] * [http://en.pzs.si/koce.php?pid=115 on Planinska zveza] {{DEFAULTSORT:Grmovskov dom pod Veliko Kopo}} [[Category:Mountain huts in Slovenia]] [[Category:Pohorje]] {{Slovenia-geo-stub}} {{Slovenia-stub}}

page.title: Guernsey Grammar School and Sixth Form Centre

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2018}} {{coord|49.450|-2.570|display=title|region:GB_scale:5000}} {{Infobox School |name = The Grammar School and Sixth Form Centre |native_name = |latin_name = |image = Guernsey Grammar School.jpg |imagesize = |caption = Qui veult peult (''Those who want to, can'') |location = |region = Les Varendes |city = St Andrew's |state = Guernsey |province = Channel Islands |county = |postcode = GY6 8TD |postalcode = |headteacher = Mrs Coffey |homepage = http://www.grammar.sch.gg }} The '''Grammar School and Sixth Form Centre''' is a public [[grammar school]] located in [[St Andrew's, Guernsey|St. Andrew's]] in [[Guernsey]].
The school's motto is ''Qui veult peult'' ([[Norman French]]:'Those who want to, can').
The mixed gender school is for students aged 11–18 and entry requires passing of the [[11-plus]] tests for those aged 11-16. It admits students from across the [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]]. However, students from other secondary schools in Guernsey who want to pursue [[Advanced Level (UK)|A Levels]] or the [[IB Diploma Programme]] transfer to the school after [[GCSE]]s.
The current school is the result of the amalgamation of the old Girls' and Boys' Intermediate Schools. The school was opened in 1985 and the current headteacher is Elizabeth Coffey.
The school had one student who was awarded the [[Victoria Cross]] during [[World War I]].
The Sixth Form Centre was opened in 2005. It was built to accommodate the rising number of students wishing to continue their education after GCSEs, studying for AS and A Levels. The school was awarded the [[Healthy Schools Standard]] in 2005.
== Previous Headmasters == Tina Watson was headteacher from 2010 to 2015, having previously been the Director of Sixth Form Studies at the school.
Jeff Smith came to The Grammar School and Sixth Form Centre after a job as "Representative of the British Education Department" in [[Indonesia]].
Dennis Balls is now retired.
==See also== *[[List of schools in Guernsey]]
== External links == *[http://www.grammar.sch.gg Guernsey Grammar School website] {{Guernsey Schools}} [[Category:Schools in Guernsey|Grammar School Guernsey]] [[Category:Secondary schools in British Crown Dependencies]] [[Category:Sixth form colleges in British Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies]] {{ChannelIslands-school-stub}} {{guernsey-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Hollow City | image = Hollow city2004.jpg | caption = Still | director = [[Maria João Ganga]] | producer = François Gonot | writer = [[Maria João Ganga]] | starring = [[João Roldan]]
[[Domingos Fernandes Fonseca]] | music = Manu Dibango & Né Gonçalves | cinematography = Jacques Besse | editing = Pascale Chavance | distributor = [[The Global Film Initiative]] | released = {{Film date|2004}} | runtime = 88 minutes | country = [[Angola]] | language = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | budget = }} '''''Hollow City''''' (''Na Cidade Vazia'') (2004) is the first full-length movie directed by [[Angola]]n-born director [[Maria João Ganga]]. The film is one of the first to be produced in Angola since the end of the [[Angolan Civil War|civil war]], and the first film produced by an Angolan woman. Filming was done on location in [[Luanda]], Angola. International versions of the film are in the [[Portuguese Language|Portuguese]] language with [[English Language|English]] [[subtitles]].{{cite web|title=HOLLOW CITY a film by Maria João Ganga|url=http://www.globalfilm.org/catalogue/hollow_city.htm|publisher=globalfilm.org|accessdate=24 March 2014}}{{cite web|title=fandor|url=http://www.fandor.com/films/hollow_city|publisher=fandor.com|accessdate=24 March 2014}}{{cite web|title=African Cinema: Media Resources Center UCB|url=http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/MRC/Africanfilm.html|publisher=lib.berkeley.edu|accessdate=24 March 2014}} ==See also== * [[Global Film Initiative]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0397557|title=Hollow City}} [[Category:2004 films]] [[Category:Angolan films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Films set in Angola]] [[Category:Portuguese-language films]] {{Angola-stub}} {{Africa-film-stub}}

{{Infobox language |name=Kuba |nativename=''Likuba'' |region= |states=[[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] |speakers={{sigfig|30200|2}} |date=2000 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantoid languages|Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone C|Zone C]]) |fam6=[[Bangi–Ntomba languages|Bangi–Ntomba]] (C.30,
traditionally C.20 Mboshi) |fam7=Bangi–Moi |iso3=kxx |glotto=liku1242 |glottorefname=Likuba |guthrie=C.27 }} '''Kuba''' (Likuba, Kyba) is a [[Bantu language]] of [[Kasai-Oriental|Kasai]], [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]. ''Ethnologue'' reports that it is [[mutually intelligible]] with [[Kwala language|Kwala]], in the C.20 group where it was classified by Guthrie 1948. However, Nurse & Philippson (2003), it belongs with the Bangi–Ntomba group, C.30. ==References== {{Reflist}} *Nurse & Philippson (2003), ''The Bantu Languages.'' {{Narrow Bantu languages|C-D}} [[Category:Bangi-Ntomba languages]] {{Bantu-lang-stub}}

revision.comment: added [[Category:Telecommunications companies of North Korea]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{refimprove |date= July 2012}} {{confusing |date= November 2008}} {{context|date=February 2013}} {{update|date=February 2013}} }} [[File:Grand-Peoples-Study-House-Computer-Lab.jpg|thumb|A computer room equipped with access to Kwangmyong at the [[Grand People's Study House]] in [[Pyongyang]]]]
'''Kwangmyong''' ({{Korean|hangul=광명|hanja=光明|context=north}}; English: Light) is a [[North Korea]]n "[[walled garden (technology)|walled garden]]" [[national intranet]] service<ref name=NYT011013>{{cite news|title=Google Chief Urges North Korea to Embrace Web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/11/world/asia/eric-schmidt-bill-richardson-north-korea.html|accessdate=January 10, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 10, 2013|author=Andrew Jacobs}}</ref> opened in 2000.
The network uses [[domain name]]s under the [[.kp]] top level domain that are not accessible from the global Internet.<ref name="YLE 2016">{{Cite web | title = Yle Pohjois-Koreassa: Kurkista suljetun maan omaan tietoverkkoon | trans-title = Yle in North Korea: Peek into the Network of the Closed Country | first = Mika | last = Mäkeläinen | publisher = Yle | date = 14 May 2016 | accessdate = 15 May 2016 | url = http://yle.fi/uutiset/yle_pohjois-koreassa_kurkista_suljetun_maan_omaan_tietoverkkoon/8882096 | language = fi }}</ref> As of 2016 the network uses [[IPv4]] addresses reserved for [[private network]]s in the 10.0.0.0/8 range.<ref name="YLE 2016" /> North Koreans often find it more convenient to access sites by their [[IP address]] rather than by [[URL]] using Latin characters.<ref name="YLE 2016" /> Like the global [[Internet]], the network hosts content accessible with [[web browser]]s, and provides an internal [[web search engine]]. It also provides [[email]] services and [[news group]]s.<ref name="yout_Comp"/>
Only a small number of government officials and tourists are allowed to use the global [[Internet in North Korea]], making Kwangmyong the only computer network available to most North Korean citizens. It is a free service for public use.
==Content== The Kwangmyong network is composed of multiple websites and services, including but not limited to: political, economic, scientific and cultural information and fields of knowledge among other topics; an [[email]]ing service; a [[social networking service]];<ref name=wp-20130313>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/03/13/a-rare-glimpse-of-north-koreas-version-of-facebook/ |title=A rare glimpse of North Korea's version of Facebook |author=Caitlin Dewey |newspaper=Washington Post |date=13 March 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> domestic news services; scientific research websites of academic and scholarly works devoted to the network through web-based academic exchanges and information sharing such as the Academy of Sciences for Science and Technology ({{korean|hangul=과학기술전시관|hanja=科學技術展示館|context=north}})<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stic.ac.kp/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130815143601/http://www.stic.ac.kp/ |archivedate=2013-08-15 |df= }}</ref> and the Academy of Sciences for Medical Science ({{korean|hangul=의학과학정보센터|context=north}});<ref>http://www.icms.he.kp/{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> websites of various [[Government of North Korea|North Korean government agencies]] including provincial government, cultural institutions, universities and some of the major industrial and commercial organizations; [[Internet censorship|censored]] websites from the Internet (mostly related to [[science]]) that are downloaded, undergo review and censorship, and publication on the Kwangmyong;<ref name="yout_Comp">{{Cite web| title = Computer Science in the DPRK [31c3]| author = Will Scott| website = media.ccc.de| publisher = [[Chaos Computer Club]]| date = 29 December 2014| accessdate = 26 June 2017| url = https://media.ccc.de/v/31c3_-_6253_-_en_-_saal_2_-_201412292115_-_computer_science_in_the_dprk_-_will_scott}}</ref> an electronic library;<ref>http://www.elib.edu.kp/{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and a few [[e-commerce]] websites by commercial organizations.<ref name=baron-20130311>{{cite web |url=http://38north.org/2013/03/jbaron031113/ |title=Book Review: A CAPITALIST IN NORTH KOREA |author=Jeff Baron |work=38 North |publisher=School of Advanced International Studies |date=11 March 2013 |accessdate=11 March 2013}}</ref> As of 2014, Kwangmyong is estimated to have between 1,000 and 5,500 websites.<ref name=ts-20140223>{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2014/02/23/north_korea_where_the_internet_has_just_5500_sites.html |title=North Korea: Where the Internet has just 5,500 sites |author=Eric Talmadge |newspaper=Toronto Star |agency=Associated Press |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>
==Network access== Kwangmyong is only accessible from within North Korea. Access is available within major cities and counties, as well as universities and major industrial and commercial organizations. There are several [[internet cafe|internet cafés]] in [[Pyongyang]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Khazan|first1=Olga|title=What it’s like to use the Internet in North Korea|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2012/12/11/what-its-like-to-use-the-internet-in-north-korea/|accessdate=19 July 2016|publisher=Washington Post|date=December 11, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Jung|first1=Yang|title=Controlling Internet Café in North Korea|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk00300&num=206|accessdate=19 July 2016|agency=DailyNK}}</ref>
Kwangmyong has 24-hour unlimited access by [[dial-up]] telephone line. {{As of|2013}}, a number of [[Android (operating system)|Android]] based [[tablet computer]] products, including the [[Samjiyon tablet computer]], can be purchased in North Korea that give access to Kwangmyong.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.itworld.com/367228/android-tablet-gives-rare-glimpse-north-korean-tech |title=Android tablet gives rare glimpse at North Korean tech |author=Martyn Williams |newspaper=IT World |date=30 July 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>
==Languages== {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2016}} The network uses [[Korean language|Korean]] as the main interface language, and is maintained by more than 2,000 language experts, according to official information, in expanding services in [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]] and [[Japanese language|Japanese]], in which there is a real-time, online translation service for the seven languages, with a database containing over 2,000,000 words, to assist users who may not be familiar with foreign languages.
==Information control== {{citation needed span|text=Kwangmyong is designed to be used only within North Korea, and referred to as an "intranet". Kwangmyong prevents domestic users within North Korea from accessing foreign content or information and prevents the leakages of classified data. It functions as a form of information censorship, preventing undesirable information from being accessed. Thus, sensitive topics and information are unlikely to surface on Kwangmyong due to the absence of a link to the outside world and the censorship that occurs. Kwangmyong is maintained by government-related entities. However, large amounts of material from the Internet end up on Kwangmyong, following processing.|date=January 2018}}
Foreigners in North Korea are generally not allowed to access Kwangmyong but may have access to the global Internet. For security reasons networks with Internet and intranet access are [[Air gap (networking)|air gapped]] so that computers with Internet access are not housed in the same location as computers with Kwangmyong access.<ref name="yout_Comp"/>
Given that there is no direct connection to the outside Internet, unwanted information cannot enter the network. Information is filtered and processed by government agencies before being hosted on the North Korean Intranet.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} [[Burma]] and [[Cuba]] also use a similar network system that is separated from the rest of the Internet,<ref name="rhoads" /> and [[Iran]] has been reported as having future plans to implement such a network, though it's claimed that it would work alongside the [[Internet]] and wouldn't replace it.<ref name="rhoads">Christopher Rhoads and Farnaz Fassihi, May 28, 2011, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704889404576277391449002016 Iran Vows to Unplug Internet], Wall Street Journal</ref>
==See also== {{portal|North Korea|Internet}} *[[Internet in North Korea]] *[[Internet censorship in North Korea]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.northkoreatech.org/2015/07/06/a-peek-inside-north-koreas-intranet/ List of sites on Kwangmyong] at [[North Korea Tech]] *[http://areena.yle.fi/1-3462510 Video of surfing on Kwangmyong] at [[Yle]] Areena *[http://www.economist.com/world/asia/displaystory.cfm?story_id=8640881 North Korea and the Internet] at ''[[The Economist]]'' *[http://www.nkeconwatch.com/category/dprk-organizations/companies/korea-computer-center-kcc/kwangmyong-computer-network/ Kwangmyong computer network] at [[North Korea Economy Watch]] *[http://www.icasinc.org/2002/2002l/2002ltxb.html Digital Divide on the Korean Peninsula] at [[Institute for Corean-American Studies]] *[https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/csi-studies/studies/vol48no1/article04.html Hermit Surfers of P'yongyang] at [[CIA]]
{{Asia topic|Internet in}}

{{For|the album by Congolese musician Kanda Bongo Man|Kwassa Kwassa (album)}} {{refimprove|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox music genre |name=Kwassa kwassa |bgcolor=deepskyblue |color=white |stylistic_origins=[[Soukous]] - [[zouk]]
|cultural_origins=1970s in Democratic Republic of Congo |instruments={{hlist|Guitar (esp. [[Fingerpicking|fingerstyle]])|bass (esp. [[Acoustic bass guitar|acoustic]])|drums|[[brass instrument|brass]]|vocals}} |popularity=In the [[world music]] scene from the 1980s |derivatives=[[Ndombolo]] |subgenrelist= |subgenres= |fusiongenres= |regional_scenes=Congolese sound ([[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Paris]]) |other_topics=[[List of soukous musicians|Soukous musicians]] }}
'''Kwassa kwassa''' (or '''kwasa kwasa''') is a dance created by Jeannora who was a mechanic in Kinshasa from the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] that started in the 1980s where the hips move back and forth while the hands move to follow the hips. It was very popular in [[Africa]] .
The dance was popularized by [[soukous]] music videos, as well as the videos of [[Kanda Bongo Man]], Pepe Kalle, [[Viva La Musica]], and other Congolese musicians. For the first time in Congo all the groups adopted these dance steps which had not happened before, because bands preferred to have their own specific dance.
==Etymology== The words ''kwassa kwassa'' may have come from the [[French language|French]] ''quoi ça?'' ("what [is] that?").
==Origins== In the 1980s, [[Kanda Bongo Man]], a Paris-based artist, pioneered fast, short [[soukous]] tracks suitable for play on dance floors everywhere and popularly known as ''kwassa kwassa'' after the dance moves popularized by his and other artists' music videos. This music appealed to Africans and to new audiences as well. Artists like [[Diblo Dibala]], Jeannot Bel Musumbu, [[Mbilia Bel]], [[Yondo Sister]], Tinderwet, [[Loketo]], [[Rigo Star]], [[Madilu System]], [[Soukous Stars]] and veterans like [[Pepe Kalle]] and [[Koffi Olomide]] followed suit. Soon Paris became home to talented studio musicians who recorded for the African and Caribbean markets and filled out bands for occasional tours.
A slower version of this genre has been created and popularized by [[Koffi Olomide]] and his band Quartier Latin. Their songs have enjoyed massive airplay throughout Africa in countries like [[Botswana]], [[Zambia]], [[Zimbabwe]], [[South Africa]], [[Senegal]] and others. Metavo is also very popular in South Africa.
This kind of beat is referenced in the 2008 song "[[Cape Cod Kwassa Kwassa]]" by American indie rock band [[Vampire Weekend]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/cape-cod-kwassa-kwassa-single/id288106666|title=iTunes - Music - Cape Cod Kwassa Kwassa - Single by Vampire Weekend|work=iTunes|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kwassa Kwassa}} [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo music]] [[Category:African dances]]
{{DRCongo-stub}}

revision.text:
[[:id:Berkas:Marsinah.jpg|A picture of Marsinah]] '''Marsinah''' (b. Nglundo, [[East Java]], April 10th, 1969 – d. approx. May 8th, 1993) was a worker [[Activism|activist]] at an [[Indonesia|Indonesian]] company, PT Catur Putra Surya in [[Porong]], [[East Java]], whose rape and murder drew international attention to the practices of the [[New Order (Indonesia)|Suharto dictatorship]] and the [[Oppression|suppression]] of workers. Marsinah was serving as a [[Negotiation|negotiator]] for 500 workers [[General strike|striking]] over supplemental payments for food and transportation. On May 4th, she was kidnapped following a demonstration, her body found four days later.<ref>Hellwig and Tagliacozzo (2009). ''The Indonesia Reader: History, Culture, Politics.'' Duke University Press. Durham and London. p 393</ref> Those responsible have never been brought to justice, but it is widely believed that the military had a hand in her disappearance and subsequent death.<ref name="Khoir">{{Cite web|url=http://www.marxist.com/marsinah-inspiration-for-working-class-struggle.htm|title=Marsinah: An Inspiration For the Working Class Struggle|last=Khoir|first=Fatkhul|website=www.marxist.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref>
The second child of Sumini and Mastin, Marsinah grew up under the care of her grandmother, Puirah, and her aunt Sini, in Nglundo, East Java. She went to school at Karangasem Public School 189, subsequently Nganjuk No.5 Middle School. Her girlhood years were marked with commerce, selling snacks in order to augment her grandmother and aunt's incomes. Marsinah's final school years were spent at the Muhammadiyah Boarding School, her educational advancement being denied due to lack of money.
Unable to find employment in Nglundo, Marsinah turned her attention to the big cities, sending in job applications to [[Surabaya]], [[Mojokerto]] and [[Gresik]]. Hired by [[Bata Shoes]] to work at their Surabaya factory in 1989, she moved a year later to the Catur Putra Surya (formerly Empat Putra Surya) watch factory in [[Sidoarjo Regency|Sidoarjo.]] Making a lateral transfer to their [[Porong]] factory after its opening, Marsinah eventually found herself serving as spokesperson for her fellow workers.
When, in 1993, the Governor of East Java announced a raise in the provincial minimum wage, Catur Putra Surya (a company with ties to the Indonesian military-industrial complex) refused to comply due to the perceived potential financial losses it would cost the company. On May 3rd of that year, CPS workers went on strike while Marsinah went to the [[Ministry of Labor|Indonesian Ministry of Labor]] to retrieve a copy of the gubernatorial directive to shove in the face of CPS management.
On May 5th, the Sidoarjo District Military Command summoned 13 workers to its headquarters and forced them to sign letters of resignation, with 8 more to follow in the next couple of days. Outraged by this turn of events, Marsinah decided to go there herself and demand an explanation that very same day. She was never seen alive again.<ref name="Khoir" />
She was posthumously awarded the [[Yap Thiam Hien Award]], and her murder was officially noted by the [[International Labour Organization]] as Case# 1773.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=NORMLEXPUB:50002:0::NO::P50002_COMPLAINT_TEXT_ID:2903024|title=FOA case text|website=www.ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref>
<references/>
==External links== * [http://workers.labor.net.au/132/news95_indon.html Megawati Reopens Marsinah Case] ''Workers Online'', 19 April 2002, Accessed 13 May 2009. * [https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDONESI949.PDF The Limits of Openness: Human Rights in Indonesia and East Timor] ''Human Rights Watch'', September 1994.

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} The [[Romanian language]] is used in [[Vojvodina]], an autonomous province of [[Serbia]], at the provincial as well as the local level. The '''National Council of the Romanian National Minority in Serbia''', an institution aiming to maintain minority autonomy in the domains of culture, education, information and the official use of the Romanian language, represents all the [[Romanians in Serbia]].<ref>Costa Roşu: [http://www.libertatea.rs/cutenews/search.php?misc=search&subaction=showfull&id=1136041742&archive=&cnshow=news&start_from=& „''Se potolesc spiritele în etnia noastră''“] {{ro icon}}, published in ''[[Libertatea (newspaper in Voivodina)|Libertatea]]'', 31 December 2005</ref>

{{Expand Japanese|ニッポン放送|date=May 2009}} {{redirect|Nippon Hōsō|Nippon Hōsō Kyōkai|NHK}} {{Infobox company| name = Nippon Broadcasting System, Inc.
株式会社ニッポン放送| type = Kabushiki gaisha| foundation = {{start date|2006|4|1}} (spun off from the former Nippon Broadcasting System, Inc. founded in 1954) | location = 9-3, Yurakucho Itchome, [[Chiyoda, Tokyo]], Japan| industry = Broadcasting| num_employees = 144 (June 2017) | parent = [[Fuji Media Holdings]]| owner = }} {{Infobox Radio station| name = Nippon Broadcasting System, Inc.
株式会社ニッポン放送 | image =| city = [[Tokyo]]| area = [[Kanto region]]| branding = {{nihongo|'''AM Radio 1242 Nippon Hōsō'''|AMラジオ1242ニッポン放送|AM Rajio ichi ni yo ni Nippon Hōsō}} | slogan = {{nihongo|[http://www.1242.com/2012kaihen/ From Yūrakuchō, Nippon Hōsō makes you smile anywhere.]|有楽町からスマイル♪ どんなときもニッポン放送|[[Yūrakuchō]] kara sumairu, donna to kimo Nippon Hōsō.}} (since April 2012) | frequency = 1242 [[Kilohertz|kHz]] (AM), 93.0 MHz (FM) | format = [[Talk radio|Talk]], [[Sports radio|Sports]] | power = 100,000 [[watt]]s | airdate = July 15, [[1954 in radio|1954]] | affiliations = [[National Radio Network (Japan)|NRN]] | webcast = http://radiko.jp/#LFR | website = [http://www.1242.com/ 1242.com]| }} {{Nihongo|'''Nippon Broadcasting System, Inc.'''|株式会社ニッポン放送|Kabushiki-gaisha Nippon Hōsō}}, or '''JOLF''', is a [[Japan]]ese [[radio station]] in [[Yurakucho]], [[Chiyoda ward]], [[Tokyo]], next to the [[Tokyo Imperial Palace]]. Founded in 1954, it is together with [[Nippon Cultural Broadcasting]], the flagship station of the [[National Radio Network (Japan)|National Radio Network]]. Nippon Broadcasting System is a subsidiary of [[Fuji Media Holdings]] and both companies are affiliated with the [[Fujisankei Communications Group]]. It is also the main company of the Nippon Broadcasting Group.https://web.archive.org/web/20150924015921/http://www.fujisankei-g.co.jp/pdf/fcglist_up_150626.pdf Nippon Broadcasting System was instrumental in the creation of several companies including [[Fuji Television]] in 1957, [[Pony Canyon]] in 1966 and the [[Fujisankei Communications Group]] in 1967.http://articles.latimes.com/1990-10-29/news/mn-2454_1_largest-mediahttp://www.ponycanyon.co.jp/comp/profile.htmlhttp://kigyoka.com/news/magazine/magazine_20130508.html Nippon Broadcasting System is also the home of the long-running radio program ''[[All Night Nippon]]''. From July 15, 1954 to September 30, 1967, the station used the abbreviation "NBS" derived from Nippon Broadcasting System. Since October 1, 1967, it has used the call sign JOLF and identified itself with the last two letters "LF". In 1990, Nippon Broadcasting System sued its rival [[Radio Nippon]] to prevent it from using both the "R · F · Radio Japan" and "Radio Japan" trademarks. Nippon Broadcasting System lost the lawsuit.http://www.courts.go.jp/app/files/hanrei_jp/674/014674_hanrei.pdf A [[labor union]] was formed at Nippon Broadcasting System for the first time in September 12, 2005. https://web.archive.org/web/20051225201232/http://it.nikkei.co.jp/business/special/fuji_livedoor.aspx?i=2005091210241ra Nippon Broadcasting System was historically the parent company of [[Fuji Television]] despite the latter being a much larger company than the former. https://books.google.ca/books?id=sUUehPO7CdwC&pg=PA216&lpg=PA216&dq=japan+upswing+fuji+nippon&source=bl&ots=DPlIj3j-OG&sig=C4RedZgGQs18Vozq1sRD-KEoneo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO3MflypTYAhVJ74MKHWRVCwUQ6AEIOTAH#v=onepage&q=japan%20upswing%20fuji%20nippon&f=falsehttp://kigyoka.com/news/magazine/magazine_20130508.html Both companies were founded in the 1950s and were part of the [[Fujisankei Communications Group]].https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/03/business/japanese-get-music-stake.html?pagewanted=1https://www.webcitation.org/5mv1vxC6q?url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/obituaries/nobutaka-shikanai-is-dead-at-78-founder-of-japanese-media-group.html In 2005, the relation between the two companies was reversed and Nippon Broadcasting System became the subsidiary of Fuji Television. https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2005/06/25/business/nbs-officially-announces-it-will-be-fuji-tv-subsidiary/#.Wk2N3HlG21s In April 2006, the radio broadcaster and its station license was spun off into a new separate company called "Nippon Broadcasting System" owned by Fuji Television.http://www.fujimediahd.co.jp/en/ir/pdf/er/fy2006/er1125_1.pdf Fuji Television absorbed the rest of the old Nippon Broadcasting System company that was founded in 1954 and took over its assets. As a result, former subsidiaries of Nippon Broadcasting System such as [[Pony Canyon]] were transferred to Fuji Television who was later renamed Fuji Media Holdings in 2008. ==Reference== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.1242.com/|JOLF}} {{ja icon}} *{{official website|www.jolf.co.jp/|Corporate Home Page}} {{ja icon}} {{coord|35.675203|139.760646|display=t|type:landmark}} [[Category:Radio in Japan]] [[Category:Media companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1954]] [[Category:Fuji Television]] [[Category:Fujisankei Communications Group]] {{Tokyo Radio}} {{Asia-radio-station-stub}} {{japan-company-stub}}

{{Use American English|date=March 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = OPS 5114 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]]
Technology | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1978-112A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1978-112A|title=Navstar 4|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=25 June 2012}} | SATCAT = 11141 | mission_duration = 5 years (planned)
11 years (achieved) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block I]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|759|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|11 December 1978, 03:59|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Atlas E/F]] [[SGS-1]],}} 39F | launch_site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 3|SLC-3E]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|May 1990}} | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20163|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20201|km}} | orbit_inclination = 63.2 degrees | orbit_period = 717.96 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''OPS 5114''', also known as '''Navstar 4''', '''GPS I-4''' and '''GPS SVN-4''', was an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] launched in 1978 as part of the [[Global Positioning System]] development programme. It was the fourth of eleven [[GPS Block I|Block I]] GPS satellites to be launched. ==Launch== OPS 5114 was launched at 03:59 UTC on 11 December 1978, atop an [[Atlas E/F]] carrier rocket with an [[SGS-1]] upper stage. The Atlas used had the serial number 39F, and was originally built as an [[SM-65F Atlas|Atlas F]].{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=12 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 3|Space Launch Complex 3E]] at [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]].{{cite web |url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html |title=Launch List |publisher=Jonathan's Space Page |work=Launch Vehicle Database |first=Jonathan |last=McDowell |accessdate=12 July 2012}} ==Orbit== OPS 5114 was placed into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-27]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar.htm|title=GPS (Navstar)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=12 July 2012}} By 1 February 1979, OPS 5114 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20163|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20201|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.96 minutes, and 63.2 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=12 July 2012}} The satellite had a design life of 5 years and a mass of {{convert|758|kg}}. It broadcast the PRN 08 signal in the GPS demonstration constellation, and was retired from service on 14 October 1989. On 20 February 1990 it was reactivated for further testing, before being deactivated again in May 1990. {{Clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1978 in spaceflight]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1978}} [[Category:1978 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1978]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{Infobox book | name = People and dogs | image = Peopleanddogs.jpg | caption = | title_orig = El nas we El Kelab | orig_lang_code = ar | translator = | cover_artist = | author = Moawad GadElrab | genre = Short stories, literature, [[Egyptian literature]], [[Arabic literature]] | publisher = The National Publishing and Printing house in [[Cairo]], Egypt | pub_date = 1964 | media_type = Print (paperback) | pages = 124 }}
[[File:Mowad Gadelrab.jpeg|thumb|Dr.Mowad Gadelrab, writer, artist]] '''''People and dogs''''' (''El nas we El Kelab'', {{lang-ar|الناس والكلاب}}) is a book of short stories written by the Egyptian physician Dr [[Moawad GadElrab]] (15 September 1929 – 23 August 1983), published by The National Publishing and Printing house in [[Cairo]], Egypt 1964.
Many of his work been adapted for television production.
==The book contains many short stories, including== The Demon, Another woman, Because my brother, Do not speed up the pace, Witness on the Nile, The rest of life, It's also For me, In hand of God, Flesh of a friend, Sakka's daughter, The cup, I'll be back tomorrow, People and dogs, Images from the past ....
==Moawad GadElrab== '''Moawad GadElrab''' (15 September 1929 – 23 August 1983) معوض جاد الرب, [[Egyptians|Egyptian]] Physician also an artist, writer, author and professor of artistic [[anatomy]] at the Faculty of Art Education, [[Zamalek]] ([[Helwan University]]) during the period of the fifties and sixties of last century.
Many of his work was adapted for television play. His articles appeared regularly in the press with weekly column in '''Watani newspaper'''.
He also participated in several [[art exhibition]] where his paintings was acquired by many official bodies .some of his paintings were displayed in '''[[Kasr El Aini Hospital|kasr Elaini]]''' [[medical college]], [[Cairo University]] where he studied medicine .
Dr. GadElrab was married and survived by two children a daughter and a son.
==See more== *[[List of Egyptian writers]]
==References== *[https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/25641566]. books on Goodreads *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/nas-wa-al-kilab/oclc/10305044] WorldCat *[http://iportal.libraries.gov.ae/cgi-bin/gw/chameleon?sessionid=2010102811124524143&skin=mcycd&lng=ar&inst=consortium&host=172.19.1.67%2B1111%2BDEFAULT&search=AUTHID&function=MARCSCR&sourcescreen=COPVOLSCR&scant1=لطيور%20%3A%20أشعار%20للأطفال%20%2F%20شعر%20حليمة%20عيسى.&scanu1=4&authid=43730&authidu=1003&elementcount=1&t1=جاحظ،%20ابي%20عثمان،%20ت.%20868%20أو%209.&u1=1003&pos=1&totalitems=1&itempos=1&rootsearch=HISTORY] United Arab Emirates, public Libraries *[http://www.nooonbooks.com/advancedsearch/result/?q=الناس+والكلابl الكتاب الماسى]{{failed verification|date=March 2015}} *[http://www.iraqnla-iq.com/opac/fullrecr.php?nid=139984&hl=ara Iraqi national library and Archives ] *[http://www.nooonbooks.com/الناس-والكلاب-الكتاب-الماسي-.html الناس+والكلاب مكتبة نون الإلكترونية nooonbooks]

{{more footnotes|date=June 2009}} {{refimprove|date=June 2009}} [[County Kerry]] has had a long history of [[pirate radio]]. One of the first pirate radio stations was set up by Michael Donovan in the early 1970s and it was called Radio Tralee. It first broadcast on AM. It was reestablished as Kerry Local Radio (KLR) and broadcast on FM. Many other pirate stations have broadcast in Kerry over the years.
The following is a list of some of the pirate stations that broadcast in Kerry at some stage. (This list is not exhaustive and may be added to by contributors with additional information)
'''Kerry Pirate radio stations''' * '''[[Radio Tralee]]''' (Tralee) ??AM (1970s) * '''[[Kerry Local Radio]]''' (Tralee) ??FM (various frequencies in the 1980s) (104FM temporarily in 1993) * '''Kerry Community Radio - KCR''' (Tralee) 99FM (1982 to 1986) * '''[[Radio Phoenix]]''' (Tralee) ??FM (mid 1980s) * '''[[WRKY Rocky 103]]''' (Killarney in 1983 to 1986) Listowel (1987 to 1988) 99FM 103FM 104FM [Big L remnants] * '''[[Horizion Radio]]''' (Kilorglin in 1986) (Banna in 1987) 97FM 99FM 104FM [also remnants of Limerick's 'Big L'] * '''[[Southwest Radio]]''' (Killarney) 97.7FM 99.7FM 103.3FM 104FM 105FM (all 20 Watts ERP each) (according to their engineer Basil Hendrix) * '''[[MRL - Music Radio Listowel]]''' (Listowel) 99FM (30 Watts ERP)(1987 to 1988) * '''[[Kingdom 102]]''' (Killarney) 102FM (3000 Watts ERP)(1987 to 1988) * '''[[Sunshine 106]]''' (Tralee) 106.5FM (short-lived) (1992) * '''[[Shannonside Local Radio]]''' (Causeway) 104FM (short-lived) (1988) * '''[[Ballinaskellings Radio]]''' 105FM (late 1980s) * '''[[Coast 103]]''' (Tralee) 106.5FM 103FM (short-lived) (1993) * '''[[UCB Europe]]''' (Tralee) 106.5FM (relay service) (1999 to 2005) * '''[[UCB Europe]]''' (Killarney area relay) 105.0 and previously 98.0 (late 1990s to around 2005) * '''[[Dance Radio]]''' (Tralee) 104.2FM (late 1990s) * '''[[Beat FM]]''' (Tralee) 104.7FM (2000 to 2006) Originally 106FM then 104FM in 2000 and changed to 104.7 in 2002 (100 Watts). Moved up 0.1 to 104.8 in 2009 (due to '4FM' presence on 104.6) * '''[[DAG FM]]''' (Tralee) 105.5FM (2009) Founded in June 2009
''?? means information not available'' * '''Pirate stations from outside Kerry that could be received in Kerry.''' * '''WCR''' (Abbeyfeale) 96.2FM-Tralee(30W) 96FM-Mallow(50W) 98FM 101.3FM-Abbeyfeale(1000W) (late 1980s) * '''ERI''' (Cork) ??AM (10,000W) (FM signal not received in Kerry) (mid to late 1980s) * '''South Coast Radio''' (Cork) ??AM (5,000W) (FM signal not received in Kerry) (mid to late 1980s) * '''Radio Vera''' (Limerick) 97FM (5000W ERP) [Big L remnants] (1988) * '''106.4 Pirate FM''' milltown county kerry 2006-2008
==References== * [http://www.onsight.ie/liambyrne/information.php?dir=limerick_radio_site/ Liam Byrne's Radio Site]
==See also== *[[Irish pirate radio]]
